Tuning the electrochemical behaviors of N-doped LiMn x Fe1– x PO4/C via cation engineering with metal-organic framework-templated strategy Yilin Li a Zhaohui Xu b Xinyu Zhang a Zhenyu Wu a Jian-En Zhou a Jinjiang Zhang c Xiaoming Lin a ⁎ a Guangzhou Key Laboratory of Materials for Energy Conversion and Storage, Key Laboratory of Theoretical Chemistry of Environment, Ministry of Education, School of Chemistry, South China Normal University, Guangzhou 510006, Guangdong, China Guangzhou Key Laboratory of Materials for Energy Conversion and Storage Key Laboratory of Theoretical Chemistry of Environment Ministry of Education School of Chemistry South China Normal University Guangzhou 510006 Guangdong China Guangzhou Key Laboratory of Materials for Energy Conversion and Storage, Key Laboratory of Theoretical Chemistry of Environment, Ministry of Education, School of Chemistry, South China Normal University, Guangzhou 510006, Guangdong, China b National Engineering Research Center for Carbohydrate Synthesis, Key Lab of Fluorine and Silicon for Energy Materials and Chemistry of Ministry of Education, Jiangxi Normal University, Nanchang 330022, Jiangxi, China National Engineering Research Center for Carbohydrate Synthesis Key Lab of Fluorine and Silicon for Energy Materials and Chemistry of Ministry of Education Jiangxi Normal University Nanchang 330022 Jiangxi China National Engineering Research Center for Carbohydrate Synthesis, Key Lab of Fluorine and Silicon for Energy Materials and Chemistry of Ministry of Education, Jiangxi Normal University, Nanchang 330022, Jiangxi, China c Jiangmen Kanhoo Industry Co., LTD, Jiangmen 529040, Guangdong, China Jiangmen Kanhoo Industry Co., LTD Jiangmen 529040 Guangdong China Jiangmen Kanhoo Industry Co., LTD, Jiangmen 529040, Guangdong, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract An elaborated design of nitrogen-doped LiMn x Fe1- x PO4/C by metal–organic framework-templated method and cation manipulating was proposed to access compositional and morphological optimization and tunable electrochemical behavior. LiFePO4, as a prevailing cathode material for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), still encounters issues such as intrinsic poor electronic conductivity, inferior Li-ion diffusion kinetic, and two-phase transformation mechanism involving substantial structural rearrangements, resulting in unsatisfactory rate performance. Carbon coating, cation doping, and morphological control have been widely employed to reconcile these issues. Inspired by these, we propose a synthetic route with metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) as self-sacrificial templates to simultaneously realize shape modulation, Mn doping, and N-doped carbon coating for enhanced electrochemical performances. The as-synthesized LiMn x Fe1– x PO4/C (x = 0, 0.25, and 0.5) deliver tunable electrochemical behaviors induced by the MOF templates, among which LiMn0.25Fe0.75PO4/C outperforms its counterparts in cyclability (164.7 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.5 C) and rate capability (116.3 mA h g−1 at 10 C). Meanwhile, the ex-situ XRD reveals a dominant single-phase solid solution mechanism of LiMn0.25Fe0.75PO4/C during delithiation, contrary to the pristine LiFePO4, without major structural reconstruction, which helps to explain the superior rate performance. Furthermore, the density functional theory (DFT) calculations verify the effects of Mn doping and embody the superiority of LiMn0.25Fe0.75PO4/C as a LIB cathode, which well supports the experimental observations. This work provides insightful guidance for the design of tunable MOF-derived mixed transition-metal systems for advanced LIBs. Keywords LiMn x Fe1– x PO4/C Mn doping Metal-organic framework Cathode 1 Introduction With the growing energy demands for effective energy storage devices, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have gradually risen to prominence due to their considerable energy density, outstanding rate performance, prolonged cycle life, and environmental friendliness [1,2]. Cathode technology plays a significant role in energy capacity and cost-effectiveness for high-performance LIBs. LiFePO4 has emerged as a prevailing viable cathode material for large-scale applications, owing to natural Fe element abundance, high theoretical capacity (170 mA h g−1), a proper operating voltage plateau (3.45 V), excellent electrochemical safety, and great thermal stability [3]. Nevertheless, hindered by its subpar energy density (578 W h kg−1), LiFePO4 can no longer satisfy the increasing requirements for electric vehicles. In contrast, another olivine cathode LiMnPO4 provides an advantage complementary in virtue of the higher working voltage (4.1 V), along with a higher theoretical energy density (700 W h kg−1), which is 21% higher than that of LiFePO4 [4]. However, LiMnPO4 exhibits intrinsically poor electronic conductivity (<10–10 S cm−1), ionic diffusivity (<10–16 cm2 s−1), and structural instability caused by the heavy polaronic holes located on the Mn3+ sites (the Jahn-Teller effect), resulting in unsatisfactory capacity retention [5]. Therefore, the substitution of partial Mn2+ for Fe2+ in LiFePO4 enables the binary LiMn x Fe1– x PO4 (LMFP) to combine the strengths of the thermal safety and structural stability of LiFePO4 as well as the higher working voltage of LiMnPO4 simultaneously, thus attracting widespread attention for LIBs with superior energy density [6]. Despite the above-mentioned advantages LMFP cathode exhibits, the inferior electronic transport and sluggish ionic diffusion based on the one-dimensional (1D) diffusion along b-axis largely limited the commercial application [7]. Over the two decades, substantial efforts have been devoted to mitigating its unsatisfactory electrochemical performance, focusing on the following aspects: (1) optimizing the Fe/Mn ratio to form a proper LMFP binary system possessing considerable energy density, significant rate performance, and stable delithiation phase [8]; (2) manipulating the morphology and minishing the particle size to shorten diffusion aisles of Li-ion and then accelerate electrochemical kinetics [9]; (3) constructing a multi-component LMFP composite with active carbon material to boost the electronic conductivity [10]. Despite the profound progress on the LMFP cathode, the effect of the Fe/Mn ratio and the related phase transition during (de)lithiation needs further exploration. More simple and effective strategies are in urgent requirement, among which the adjustment via ion manipulating could provide a feasible approach to enhance the electrochemical performances [11–13]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are three-dimensional topological coordination network materials that are constructed by metal nodes and organic linkers, possessing enormous surface area, abundant active sites, structure diversities, and high porosity [2,14]. Prussian blue (PB) is a class of MOFs with stable 3D cubic structures where alternating FeⅢ and FeⅡ are bridged by the cyanide ions [15], while the Fe species can be replaced by other transition elements such as Mn, Co, and Ni to form Prussian blue analogs (PBAs) [16]. Benefiting from the adjustable chemical compositions and diverse structural traits, PB and PBAs materials have promising applications in catalysis [17], sensors [18], and rechargeable batteries [19]. Serving as self-sacrificial templates, the PBAs sintered with Li and P sources can be calcined in the inert atmosphere to obtain PBA-derived carbonaceous polyanionic cathode materials with outstanding chemical homogeneity, which can inherit the unique morphology features of precursors and generate nitrogen-doped carbon network. Inspired by the above analysis, we propose a solid-state sintering method to synthesize the LiMn x Fe1– x PO4/C (LM x F1– x P/C, x = 0, 0.25, 0.5) cathode materials using PBA materials with controllable Fe/Mn ratio and tunable morphology as self-sacrificial templates. We systematically study the effect of Mn doping amount on particle morphology, phase transition mechanism during (de)lithiation, and electrochemical performance of the LM x F1– x P/C. According to the experimental investigation, the LM0.25F0.75P/C delivers superior cycling stability, better Li-ion diffusion kinetics, and impressive rate performance which could be due to the proper Mn doping amount, homogeneous local distribution of Fe/Mn elements, N-enriched carbon coating, and the formation of nonequilibrium single-phase solid solution making the huge volume variation and substantial structural rearrangements evitable in the (dis)charging process. The density functional theory (DFT) calculations further prove the smallest band gap and lowest deintercalation energy of LM0.25F0.75P/C among LM x F1– x P/C materials, indicating enhanced electronic conductivity, easier Li-ion deintercalation reaction, and lower energy barriers, theoretically supporting the electrochemical superiority. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material and synthesis 2.1.1 Preparation of solid Mn x Fe1– x -PBA In a traditional method [20], 6 g polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) was dissolved in the mixture of C2H5OH and H2O (200 mL/200 mL). Subsequently, different proportions of FeCl3 and MnSO4 (the dose is displayed in Table S1) were added into the PVP solution under vigorous magnetic stirring for 30 min and then sonicate for another 10 min to obtain a homogeneous solution. After that, 200 mL K3[Fe(CN)6] (20 mM) was poured into the above solution with stirring for 6 h at 60 °C. The precipitation was harvested by centrifugation and rinsed several times with ethanol and deionized water. Finally, the Mn x Fe1– x -PBA products were obtained by drying at 70 °C for 12 h in an oven. 2.1.2 Preparation of solid Mn x Fe1– x -PBA derived LiMn x Fe1– x PO4/C The LiMn x Fe1– x PO4/C was obtained by solid-state sintering using the Mn x Fe1– x -PBA nanoparticles as the precursor. At first, 0.5 g Mn x Fe1– x -PBA, 0.33 g ammonium dihydrogen phosphate (NH4H2PO4), and 0.15 g lithium carbonate (Li2CO3) were mixed in a mortar with grinding for 20 min. Subsequently, the above mixture was calcined at 650 °C for 8 h under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 in a tubular furnace to successfully synthesize the final products. 2.2 Materials characterization The chemical composition of the LiMn x Fe1– x PO4/C powders was measured by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, Agilent ICPOES730, USA). The crystallinity and phase purity of samples were investigated with the help of the X-ray powder diffractometer (XRD, UItima IV, Japan, 40 kV, 20 mA) with Cu K α radiation. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra was determined by Nicolet 5700 spectrometers with KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, TG-209F3) was performed increasing from room temperature to 800 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 in a nitrogen atmosphere. Raman spectra (Renishaw inVia, UK) were recorded in the shift range of 300–3500 cm−1 to analyze the structural information and the existence of carbon. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Shimadzu, AXIS SUPRA) with Al K α radiation was carried out to investigate the elemental composition and chemical state of products. The specific surface areas and pore size of the as-prepared samples were measured by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET, Micromeritics ASAP 2460) isotherms at 77 K under N2 condition. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, FEI Quanta 250 FEG, USA) was carried out to analyze the external morphology and frame of the precursors and products, while transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM-2100HR) studies the internal microstructure and the lattice stripes. 2.3 Electrochemical testing Electrochemical properties of the LiMn x Fe1– x PO4/C material were measured by the CR2032 coin-type cells, assembled under argon atmosphere in a glove box (O2 ≤ 0.01 ppm, H2O ≤ 0.01 ppm, Mikrouna). The active substance (LiMn x Fe1– x PO4/C powder) mixed with the conductive agent (acetylene black, Supper P) and a binder (polyvinylidene fluoride) was dissolved in N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP) solvent at a mass ratio of 8:1:1. The mass load of active materials is around 1.6 mg cm−2. After stirring for 12 h, the obtained homogeneous slurry was evenly coated on aluminum foil and then dried in vacuum oven at 110 °C for 10 h. Afterwards, the piece was trimmed into wafers with a diameter of 12 mm serving as the cathode, while the Celgard 2400 membrane as separator, lithium foil as the counter electrode, and LiPF6 dissolved in a mixture of ethylene carbonate (EC), diethyl carbonate (DC), and methylene carbonate (EMC) (1:1:1, vol%) as the electrolyte. Finally, the galvanostatic charge/discharge curves in a potential range of 2.3–4.8 V, long cycling, multiplier performance, and galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) were tested at room temperature on LANDdt test system (LAND CT 2001A). Cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests and electrochemical impedance spectra were obtained from an electrochemical workstation (CHI 760E). 2.4 Computational methods Structural optimization was implemented by Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) [21] with the help of projector augmented wave (PAW) [22]. To analyze the interactions between atoms, the exchange-functional was studied using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [23] functional accompanied with the DFT-D3 correction [24]. The cut-off energy of the plane-wave basis was set at 450 eV in structural optimization. The Brillouin zone integration was investigated with a Monkhorst-Pack k-point mesh of 0.03 Å−1 to optimize the geometry and lattice size. The Gaussian smearing method and 0.05 eV width were allowed in partial occupancies of the Kohn-Sham orbitals. Meanwhile, when the value of energy change is smaller than 0.02 eV Å−1, geometry optimization was considered convergent. The vacuum spacing in a direction perpendicular to the plane of the structure is 15 Å. To correctly descript the magnetic properties, the spin polarization was also performed. Besides, in consideration of the strong correlation effects between transition metal in crystal, the electronic structure optimization and calculations were performed with the help of the spin-dependent GGA plus Hubbard correction U method with an effective U eff value of 4.0 and 4.3 eV for Mn and Fe, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and morphology characterization The synthesis process of Mn x Fe1– x -PBA and MOF-derived LM x F1– x P/C is elaborated in Fig. 1 (a). Briefly, three Mn x Fe1– x -PBAs with diverse morphologies were obtained by coprecipitation of FeⅢ, tunable dosage of MnⅡ, and [FeⅢ(CN)6]3– , serving as Fe, Mn, and carbon source, respectively. According to the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) result (Fig. S1), the Mn x Fe1– x -PBA precursors was calcinating at 650 °C for 8 h under a nitrogen atmosphere after mixed with ammonium dihydrogen phosphate (NH4H2PO4) and lithium carbonate (Li2CO3) rendering as P and Li sources, respectively. Finally, the MOF-derived LM x F1– x P/C materials with N-doped carbon matrix were successfully synthesized. The crystal structure (Fig. S2a), XRD curves (Fig. S2b), and FT-IR spectra (Fig. S3) of PBAs jointly confirm the successful synthesis of the solid Mn x Fe1– x -PBA particles. The spectrum of Fe-PBA displays a single peak near 2100 cm−1, confirming the characteristic bonding of C≡N– to Fe3+, implying a pure phase of FeⅢFeⅢ(CN)6. Instead, the Mn0.25Fe0.75-PBA and Mn0.5Fe0.5-PBA possess two v(CN) characteristic peaks corresponding to MnⅡ–NC-FeⅢ (2149 cm−1) and MnⅢ–NC-FeⅡ (2080 cm−1), implying a mixed phase containing different compositions and the existence of transformation from structure MnⅡ–NC-FeⅢ to structure MnⅢ–NC-FeⅡ [25,26]. The crystallinity and purity of the as-prepared LM x F1– x P/C are also investigated by XRD (Fig. 1b). All characteristic peaks belong to orthorhombic Pnma space group, indicating a solid solution nature of LiFePO4 (JCPDS: 81–1173) and LiMnPO4 (JCPDS: 74–0375). Besides, the quantitative data and the molar ratio of Fe/Mn versus P elements for LM x F1– x P/C samples are obtained and displayed in Table S2 and Fig. S4(a) with the help of ICP-OES to confirm the composition of the synthesized materials. The high-resolution powder XRD and the corresponding Rietveld refinement results for LM x F1– x P/C shown in Fig. S4(b–d) were used to analyze the lattice parameter and the difference of diffraction peaks [27]. As shown in Fig. 1(c) and Fig. S4(e–i), the typical peaks including (311), (200), (101), (111), and (211) planes all shift to the left as the x value ranging from 0 to 0.5, resulting from the larger ionic radius of Mn2+ (0.097) than Fe2+ (0.092 nm) [28]. Coinciding with the XRD pattern, the obtained lattice parameters (a, b, c, and V) all increase with the increasing Mn amount according to the simulated results displayed in Fig. S5. Furthermore, FTIR spectroscopy was performed to analyze the detailed crystal structural images of LM x F1– x P/C composites (Fig. 1d). The v 1 and v 3 of stretching vibration of PO4 3– ion locate at the region of 950–1150 cm−1, while the v 4 bending mode appear in the region of 540–650 cm−1. The band between 400–540 cm−1 belong to the symmetric v 2 PO4 3– bending vibrations and Li+ motions. Notably, the P-O stretching vibrations are sensitive to the transition metal ion, whereas the bending vibrations and Li+ mode seem unaffected. According to the Tarte’s assignment, the separation of P-O v 3 stretching vibrations increase with the rising x valve as follows: Δv 3 = 1137 – 965 = 172 cm−1 for LFP/C, 1137 – 972 = 165 cm−1 for LM0.25F0.75P/C, and 1137 – 980 = 157 cm−1 for LM0.5F0.5P/C, respectively, which is associated with the ionization potential of transition metal ions [29,30]. The crystal structural models depicted in Fig. 1(e) revealed that the LM x F1– x P/C materials possess a polyoxyanionic framework. Li+ is bonded with 6 O2– anions to form LiO6 octahedra that share corners with four FeO6 (MnO6) octahedra, and corners with PO4 tetrahedra, making a stable olivine structure [31]. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) are performed to investigate the morphological features of the Mn x Fe1– x -PBAs and their derived LM x F1– x P/C. The SEM images reveal that the Fe-PBA nanoparticles are characterized by cubic geometry with smooth surface (Fig. 2a). According to the particle size analysis of Fe-PBA (Fig. S6a), the distribution of particle sizes range 200–520 nm and average 389.7 nm. After annealing, the Fe-PBA derived LFP/C transform from nanocube to dice with round edges (truncated sphere) covered with numerous tiny nanoparticles (Fig. 2b), along with slight shrinkage attributed to the high-temperature sintering (the corresponding schematic illustration is displayed in Fig. 2g). The TEM images in Fig. 2(c and d) reveal detailed internal information and the ultrafine particles on the surface, which facilitate enlarged contacting area, affluent electrochemical active sites, released volume variation, and fast Li-ion diffusion. Furthermore, the high-magnification TEM (HRTEM) image (Fig. 2e) depicts the well-resolved lattice fringes with the interplanar d-spacings of 0.28 and 0.25 nm, corresponding to the (301) and (311) lattice planes, respectively, belong to the olivine phase in LFP. And the ring-like selected area electron (SAED) pattern displayed in Fig. 2(f) manifests the major diffraction rings identified with the (101), (211), (311), and (130) planes of LiFePO4. As displayed in Fig. 2(h), the high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) and element mappings reveal the distribution of Fe, P, O, C, and N, coincided with the dice-shape, demonstrating the even elemental distribution in LFP/C and the successful nitrogen doping. Notably, N-doped carbon matrix derived from PBA precursor can serve as both template and morphology protector, further achieving reinforced structure, enhanced electronic conductivity, and accelerated Li-ion diffusion transportation, which is favorable to realize outstanding cycling stability and outstanding rate performance [32]. The SEM image of Mn0.25Fe0.75-PBA (Fig. 3 a) demonstrates a spherical structure covered by a shell composed of abundant ultrafine particles. Interestingly, Mn-doping generated enormous tiny nanoparticles around 10–20 nm, implying Mn2+ simulated a phase transition in PBA crystal, which is consistent with the FT-IR results. Meanwhile, the Mn0.25Fe0.75-PBA particles possess uniform particle diameters of 140–280 nm with an average size of 211.9 nm (Fig. S6b), indicating that Mn-doping resulted in a decrease of particle size of Mn x Fe1– x -PBA, which may be associated with that the crystal growth of parent crystals are hindered by the dilution of solute with doping ions [33,34]. Herein, the morphology and size of PBAs particles can be tailored by modulating the Fe/Mn ratio. Accordingly, Fig. 3(b) revealed that the Mn0.25Fe0.75-PBA-derived LM0.25F0.75P/C product inherits the morphological characteristics of the precursor but with the rougher surface and looser porous structure (Fig. 3g). TEM images in Fig. 3(c and d) with detailed internal structural information matched well with the SEM images and the contrasting light and shade further confirm the core–shell mixed phase of Mn0.25Fe0.75-PBA precursor. After annealing, the LM0.25F0.75P/C undergoes the structural evolution toward a hollow structure with the well retained parent morphology of the MOF template, in which the enriched void spaces of the LM0.25F0.75P/C primary particles are imparted by the Kirkendall effect during the thermolysis process in an inert atmosphere [35]. More specifically, the nanoscale Kirkendall effect, which refers to vacancy creation resulting from the directional diffusion of atoms in a diffusion couple, can be used to explain the formation of the void structure [35]. The HRTEM image in Fig. 3(e) depicts the contiguous lattice fringes with lattice spacings of 0.52, 0.35, and 0.25 nm, correlating to the (200), (111), and (311) facets of the olivine phase in LM0.25F0.75P/C. As displayed the Fig. 3(f), the SAED pattern reveals the characteristic diffraction rings of (200), (101), and (211) planes in the olivine phase in LiMn x Fe1– x P. The HAADF-STEM pattern and corresponding element mappings (Fig. 3h and Fig. S7) illustrate the distribution of Mn, Fe, P, O, C, and N, which coincide with the sphere shape, indicating the homogeneous elemental distribution in LM0.25F0.75P/C and the successful nitrogen doping. The N-doped porous spherical structure covered by a shell composed of abundant ultrafine particles provides abundant active electrochemical sites, sufficient electrolyte/electrode contact area, and adequate room for volume variation, thus facilitating boosted electronic conductivity, accelerated charge diffusivity, and cycling structural stability. As shown in Fig. 4(a), the Mn0.5Fe0.5-PBA feature in an irregular octahedron architecture covered with abundant ultrafine nanoparticles. According to the particle size analysis in Fig. S6(c), the Mn0.5Fe0.5-PBA particles possess uniform particle diameters of 150–300 nm and average 238.8 nm. After calcination, the Mn0.5Fe0.5-PBA derived LM0.5F0.5P/C (Fig. 4b) primely retains the original octahedral shape with many tiny nanoparticles distributed on the surface of the corresponding precursor but the structure also becomes looser and rougher (Fig. 4g). Accordingly, contrasting light and shade in TEM images in Fig. 4(c and d) for LM0.5F0.5P/C also indicate the core–shell structure of Mn0.5Fe0.5-PBA precursor. The well-resolved lattice fringes with the interplanar d-spacings of 0.35, 0.28, and 0.25 nm depicted in the HRTEM image (Fig. 4e) are corresponding to the (111), (301), and (311) lattice facets of the olivine phase in LM0.5F0.5P, respectively. The concentric selected area electron diffraction (SEAD) in Fig. 4(f) features the distinct diffraction rings of (111), (301), and (112) planes of LiMn x Fe1– x P. As displayed in Fig. 4(h) and Fig. S7, the HAADF-STEM pattern and corresponding element mappings reveal the distribution of Mn, Fe, P, O, C, and N, coincided with the octahedron-shape, demonstrating the homogeneous elemental distribution in LM0.5F0.5P/C and the successful doping of nitrogen. The tunable morphologies of LM x F1– x P/C can be attributed to the phase transition of PBA crystal triggered by Mn doping. According to previous reports, various external factors including temperature, cation doping, X-rays, and visible light could provoke a phase transition of PBAs [36–38]. In this work, we utilize a variable dosage of Mn2+ to stimulate the generation of a mixed phase including MnⅡ–NC-FeⅢ (cubic phase) and MnⅢ–NC-FeⅡ (tetragonal phase), forming a core–shell structure (Fig. S3). The phase variation happened may be associated with the charge-transfer from CN– to Fe3+ and subsequent charge-supplement from Mn2+ to CN– [39]. According to the FT-IR analysis in Fig. S3, the amount variation of the Mn2+ dopant allowed the morphology to evolve from cubes to irregular octahedron with the generation of tetragonal PBA phase. The effective tuning of the shape and particle size can be utilized to directionally fabricate desirable self-sacrificial templates for olivine materials with tunable morphology [40]. The Raman spectrum is used to further investigate the structural information of LM x F1– x P/C materials. The bands at around 1335 and 1590 cm−1 correspond to the bands of defective sp 3 carbon (D-band) and crystalline sp 2 carbon (G-band), respectively. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), the intensity ratios of the defective sp 3 carbon to crystalline sp 2 carbon (I D/I G) values of LM x F1– x P/C are in the range of 0.91–0.93, demonstrating a higher degree of graphitization, which is favorable for electronic conductivity [41]. And the peaks at around 960 cm−1 are associated with the intermolecular stretching motions and antisymmetric stretching modes of the PO4 3– [42]. Furthermore, the intensities of carbon peaks indicate higher carbon content of LM0.25F0.75P/C and LM0.5F0.5P/C, which is coincident with the TG analysis of LM x F1– x P/C (Fig. S8). It is worth mentioning that the transition metals with more electron d-vacancies become more reactive with carbon, and the Mn (3d 54s 2) with higher d-vacancy level than Fe (3d 64s 2) display excellent affinity, easily stabilizing carbon layers on the surface during the pyrolysis process [43,44]. Besides, the carbon content affects the quality of carbon coating on the surface, and a suitable content (∼5%) can result in uniform carbon distribution to realize enhanced electrochemical performance [45]. According to Fig. 5(b), the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas of LFP/C, LM0.25F0.75P/C, and LM0.5F0.5P/C materials are calculated as 95.8, 122.3, and 45.0 m2/g, respectively, while the adsorption curves all possess characteristic type-IV isotherms with obvious hysteresis loops, revealing the existence of both macropores and mesopores [46]. Besides, the pore structures are also studied by the pore size distribution curves in Fig. 5(c). The LM0.25F0.75P/C exhibiting the largest specific surface area is mainly associated with the smaller particle size and the porous sphere shape covered with enormous ultrafine nanoparticles. This porous structure is favorable to provide sufficient electrochemical active sites, accelerate the electrolyte infiltration, buffer volumetric expansion, and shorten the Li-ion diffusion pathway to boost the electrochemical performance [47]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was implemented to investigate the bonding configuration and the elemental chemical states of LM x F1– x P/C composites. The survey spectrum in Fig. S9 confirms the existence of Li 1s, P 2p, C 1s, N 1s, O 1s, Mn 2p, and Fe 2p and the binding energies are around 50.3, 130.4, 282.7, 400.1, 530.4, 642.5, and 713.8 eV, respectively. The high-resolution spectra of Li 1s (Fig. S10) confirm the successful lithiation through the solid-state sintering method. The fitting Fe 2p spectrum (Fig. 5d) is indexed into six subpeaks, where the characteristic peaks around 712.4 and 726.3 eV correspond to Fe 2p 3/2 and Fe 2p 1/2 with an energy separation (ΔE Fe) of 13.9 eV, reflecting the existence of Fe2+ state in LM x F1– x P/C. The peaks at 713.8 and 726.8 eV are ascribed to Fe3+, revealing the generation of a higher Fe3+ oxidation state. And the rest two peaks at 714.6 and 729.8 eV are according to the satellite. As shown in Fig. 5(e), the raw spectra of Mn 2p exhibit two main subpeaks at 642.5 and 654.1 eV, corresponding to the spin–orbit coupling Mn 2p 3/2 and Mn 2p 1/2, respectively [48]. The binding energies centered at 642.5 and 654.5 eV are attributed to Mn2+, while peaks at 644.4 and 655.6 eV are corresponded to the Mn3+ which indicated a partial oxidation in preparation. The coexistence of the tiny amount of Fe3+ and Mn3+ oxidation states (which could not be observed in XRD results) is attributed to the instability of Fe2+/Mn2+ in LM x F1– x P/C [49]. It should be noted that a handful of aliovalent ion formation is beneficial to increase the electronic conductivity, enhance the overall kinetics and thus optimize electrochemical properties [50,51]. Additionally, the obvious peaks centered at 647.1 and 656.6 eV belong to satellite peaks, further confirming the bivalent Mn [52]. As shown in Fig. 5(f), the deconvoluted O 1s spectra prove the coexistence of C–O, C=O, P–O, and Fe/Mn–O bonds centered at 533.1, 532.2, 531.5, and 530.9 eV, respectively [53]. And the P 2p spectra bearing a broad peak located at 134.2 eV in Fig. 5(g) are ascribed to the PO4 3– moiety. The C 1s spectra in Fig. 5(h) split into three peaks including the sp 2-hybridized carbon (C=C) located at 284.3 eV, the epoxy groups (C–O) at 286.1 eV, and the carbonyl groups at 287.8 eV [26]. Notably, the elemental spectra and the survey spectra of LM x F1– x P/C (0 < x < 1) show no discernible differences in the LFP/C sample, indicating that the Mn-doping would not disturb the oxidation state of composition in the LFP/C. The N 1s spectrum was indexed to three peaks appearing at 394.1, 399.2, and 401.1 eV, corresponding to pyridinic, pyrrolic, and graphitic nitrogen, respectively, proving the successful doping of nitrogen. It is of note that N-doping into carbon frame can introduce defects into a substance to enlarge the specific surface area, bring additional defect active sites and broaden the diffusion pathway, thus facilitating outstanding electronic conductivity and electrochemical kinetics [54]. 3.2 Electrochemical lithium-storage performance In order to systematically investigate the effect of Mn-doping on electrochemical performance, the LM x F1– x P/C materials were tested as cathodes for LIBs. CV measurements were performed at a sweep rate of 0.2 mV s−1 to analyze the effect of doping Mn amount on the redox potentials and the kinetic properties. As shown in Fig. 6(a), two obvious couples of peaks are corresponding to the Fe2+/Fe3+ and Mn2+/Mn3+ redox reaction as follows. (1) LiMn2+ x Fe2+ 1– x PO4 → LiMn2+ x Fe3+ 1– x PO4 + (1–x)Li+ + (1–x)e– (2) LiMn2+ x Fe3+ 1– x PO4 → Mn3+ x Fe3+ 1– x PO4 + xLi+ + xe– Obviously, the increasing Mn amount leads to the shift of the redox peaks toward higher voltage for both Fe2+/Fe3+ and Mn2+/Mn3+, resulting from the larger lattice parameters and cell volume which can decrease the covalence of the metal–oxygen bond, lower the redox energy and thereby raise the redox potentials [55]. To further analyze the potential difference between redox peaks, Fig. 6(b) separately records the peak separation between the redox potential of Fe2+/Fe3+ and Mn2+/Mn3+. As the Mn content increases, the polarization in the Fe2+/Fe3+ plateau reduces while the Mn2+/Mn3+ rises, indicating that the electrochemical delithiation Fe becomes more active accompanied by the Mn doping. Besides, the lower polarization implied faster diffusion kinetic behavior and more reversible lithiation/delithiation. Furthermore, galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) curves of LM x F1– x P/C at the 150th circle are displayed in Fig. 6(c). The LFP/C exhibits one pair of potential plateaus at around 3.4 V according to Fe2+/Fe3+ redox couples while the LM0.25F0.75P/C and LM0.5F0.5P/C possess two pairs around 3.5 and 4.1 V assigned to Fe2+/Fe3+ and Mn2+/Mn3+, respectively. Apparently, an increasing ratio of Mn/Fe leads to higher plateaus for both Fe and Mn redox couples, which is consistent with the voltage up-shift in the CV profiles. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were performed to investigate the reaction resistance. As displayed in Fig. 6(d), the Nyquist plots of three samples all contain the semicircle located at the medium-frequency area corresponding to the charge transfer-resistance (R ct) and the sloping line at the low-frequency region pertaining to Warburg impedance (W s) for Li+ migration [56]. Table S3 depicts the fitted impedance values of LM x F1– x P/C materials which are calculated through the equivalent circuit model (Fig. S11a). Compared with other LM x F1– x P/C materials, the LM0.25F0.75P/C exhibits lower R ct value and Warburg impedance, proving the higher electronic/ionic conductivities and faster Li-ion diffusion kinetics. Besides, the Li-ion diffusion coefficient (D Li +) can be quantified by the following equation (3) D Li + = R 2 T 2 / 2 A n 4 F 4 c 2 σ 2 where the R, T, A, n, F, c, and σ stand for the gas constant, temperature, surface area of the electrode, number of electrons, molar concentration of Li+, and the Warburg coefficient, respectively [57]. The σ values are obtained from the linear relationship between Z′ and ω –1/2 at the low frequency in Fig. S11(b). Accordingly, the σ equals the slope calculated to be 43.32, 19.70, and 69.78 Ω s−1/2 for LFP/C, LM0.25F0.75P/C, and LM0.5F0.5P/C, respectively. Consequently, the D Li + values are quantified to be 4.648 × 10–13, 2.247 × 10–12, and 1.791 × 10–13 cm2 s−1, respectively, indicating the faster diffusion kinetic. This can be attributed to the proper substitution of Mn (with a larger radius) for Fe, which could contort the FeO6 octahedral structure, crowd rest Fe and O atoms, thereby strengthening the interaction between Fe (4s) and O (2p) electron and facilitate the redox of Fe3+/Fe2+ to realize easier (de)lithiation [58]. Fig. 6(e) illustrated the long-term performance of MOF-derived LFP/C, LM0.25F0.75P/C, LM0.5F0.5P/C, and solvothermal synthetic LM0.25F0.75P/C (termed as S-LM0.25F0.75P/C) at the current density of 0.5 C, among which MOF-derived LM0.25F0.75P/C exhibits superior cycle stability with an outstanding reversible capacity of 164.7 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles, outperforming LFP/C (147.6 mA h g−1), LM0.5F0.5P/C (114.5 mA h g−1) and S-LM0.25F0.75P/C (89.9 mA h g−1). Moreover, the comparison of electrochemical performance for this work and recently reported LM x F1– x P/C is displayed in Fig. S12(a and b) and Table S4, further proving a considerable improvement in cycling stability and rate performance. This result demonstrates that the N-doping carbon matrix, particle morphology, and proper Fe/Mn ratio can be critical factors in cycling performance. The XRD patterns of MOF-LM x F1– x P/C cathode after cycling (Fig. S13) further confirm the crystalline stability and thermal safety. All characteristic peaks correspond to the olivine-type crystalline structure with the Pnmb space group except for the aluminum foil located at 65° and 78°, revealing excellent cycling stability and thermal safety. The rate performances of samples ranging from 0.5 to 10 C were displayed in Fig. 6(f). As expected, MOF-derived LM0.25F0.75P/C performed well with capacities of 168.3, 165.5, 164.8, 161.4, 152.3, 139.8, and 116.1 mA h g−1 at 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 10 C, respectively, while the MOF-derived LFP/C, LM0.5F0.5P/C, and the S-LM0.25F0.75P/C possess unsatisfactory reversible capacities of 96.2, 37.8, and 10.1 mA h g−1 at the exalted rate of 10 C, respectively. Promisingly, the capability (169.1 mA h g−1) can bound back rapidly in the MOF-derived LM0.25F0.75P/C as the current density recovers, further confirming the excellent reversibility and strong tolerance of the rapid transport of Li-ion which could not only be attributed to the structure superiority and compositional optimization but also associated with the nonequilibrium phase transformation mechanism [59]. To further investigate the transformation mechanism of LM x F1– x P/C cathode, the ex-situ high resolution XRD of MOF-derived LM0.25F0.75P/C and LFP/C at different states of delithiation was performed. Despite the inconspicuous presence of the two phases at the initial delithiated state showing the hysteresis in the transformation between LiMn0.25Fe0.75PO4 and Li1– x Mn0.25Fe0.75PO4, the ex-situ XRD curves of LM0.25F0.75P/C displayed in Fig. 6(g) demonstrates continuous variation in the characteristic peak position, suggestive of the predominant solid solution behavior. The lattice parameters acquired from the simulated results by Jade 6.0 software are disclosed in Fig. S14, where the Li+ extraction causes continuous extension of c axis and shrinkage of a, b, and V during the oxidation process of Fe2+/Fe3+ below 3.7 V, resulting in the successive shift of (200) and (211) facets (∼17° and ∼29°, respectively) to higher angles along with the slight shift of (101) and (111) facets (∼21° and 26°, respectively) to lower angles. Above 3.7 V upon charging, the c parameter tends to stabilize with the simultaneous declining a, b, and V values, thereby triggering the profoundly rising angles of all facets [60]. In contrast, Fig. 6(h) reveals the presence of both lithium-rich and lithium-poor phases, corresponding to the triphylite and heterosite phases, respectively, without observable diffraction angle shifts upon delithiation [61]. In order to explain the above observations, a phase transformation model was displayed as illustrated in Fig. 6(i). The delithiation of LM0.25F0.75P/C cathode proceeds through nonequilibrium solid solution formation accompanied by slightly hysteretic behavior, while the LFP/C cathode exactly follows the classical nucleation process. Noticeably, the two-phase nucleation and growth progress involving huge volume variation and substantial structural rearrangements seriously limit the ability to achieve high-rate cycling. On the contrary, the establishment of a nonequilibrium single-phase solid solution during the delithiation of LM0.25F0.75P/C, avoiding the structural reconstruction, helps to explain the high rate performance [62]. To further confirm the electrochemical superiority of LM0.25F0.75P/C, the CV curves were recorded at 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0 mV s−1 for samples to investigate the pseudocapacitive effect for Li-ion storage performance and reaction kinetics. As exhibited in Fig. 7 (a), the CV profiles maintained a similar shape with only one couple of sharp redox peaks of Fe2+/Fe3+ positioned at around 3.5 V. Two pairs of distinct redox peaks corresponding to Fe2+/Fe3+ and Mn2+/Mn3+ located at 3.5 and 4.1 V are present in LM0.25F0.75P/C, LM0.5F0.5P/C, and S-LM0.25F0.75P/C (Fig. 7b and c and Fig. S15a). The pseudocapacitive behavior can be evaluated by the equation i = avb , where i and v represent the peak current and scan rate, respectively [63]. Estimated by fitting the slope of Log(i) and Log(v), the b value can be obtained. Correspondingly, a b value near 0.5 demonstrates diffusion-controlled process, while the ones near 1.0 reveal the pseudocapacitance-dominated reaction. As shown in Figs. S15(d) and S16(a–c), the b value of peaks 1, 2, 3, and 4 for LM0.25F0.75P/C are 0.75, 0.74, 0.78, and 0.74, respectively, suggesting the combination of the diffusion and pseudocapacitance controlled behaviors, which are significantly higher than LFP/C (0.64 for peak 1 and 0.60 for peak 2), LM0.5F0.5P/C (0.65, 0.65, 0.73, 0.67 for peaks 1–4, respectively), and S-LM0.25F0.75P/C (0.62, 0.69, 0.67, 0.61 for peaks 1–4, respectively). Besides, the pseudocapacitance-dominated (k 1 v) and diffusion-controlled contribution (k 2 v) can be quantified via the formula i = k 1 v + k 2 v 1/2 [64]. According to Fig. 7(d–f), the pseudocapacitive ratio of LM0.25F0.75P/C is quantified to be 92.9% at a scan rate of 1.0 mV s−1, higher than LFP/C, LM0.5F0.5P/C, and S-LM0.25F0.75P/C (Fig. S15c). The pseudocapacitive contribution ratios for LM x F1– x P/C increased with the rising scan rates, among which LM0.25F0.75P/C exhibits more instructive pseudocapacitance-dominated kinetics than its counterparts, as presented in Fig. 7(g–i) and Fig. S15(b). Benefitting from the boosted electronic conductivity attributed to the proper Mn-doping and affluent active sites offered by the considerable specific surface area, the LM0.25F0.75P/C cathode possesses higher pseudocapacitive contribution, indicating faster kinetics reaction and hence facilitating the superior rate capability. The galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) was carried out to further evaluate the lithium diffusion kinetics at different stages of Li intercalation–deintercalation in LM x F1– x P/C electrodes. Fig. 8 (a–c) displayed the lithiation/delithiation curves of three samples obtained by GITT during the 2nd cycle in the voltage regime of 2.3–4.8 V, consistent with the galvanostatic charge/discharge curves. The GITT titration profiles depicted the voltage changes in each relaxation step upon (dis)charging in Fig. 8(d–f). According to enlarged GITT patterns in Fig. S17, the Fe2+/Fe3+ redox pairs in LM0.25F0.75P/C exhibits shorter relaxation spikes than those of other counterparts, indicating a faster reaction kinetics with reduced polarization and accelerated equilibration [65]. To further investigate the lithium diffusion kinetics, the diffusion coefficient of lithium ions can be quantified by the following formula. (4) D Li + = 4 π τ m B V M M B A 2 dE / d x dE / d t 2 ( τ < < L 2 / D Li + ) where m B (g), M B (g mol−1), and V M (cm3 mol−1) correspond to the mass, molecular weight, and molar volume of the active material, respectively, while A (cm2) and L (cm) values represent the surface area of the electrode and the length of diffusion, respectively. Eq. (4) can be simplified as Eq. (5) as follow (5) D L i + = 4 π τ m B V M M B A 2 Δ E s Δ E τ 2 where the ΔE S and ΔE τ can be obtained from the profiles of a single-step GITT titration (Fig. S18), corresponding to the change of steady-state voltage and cell voltage change, respectively. As displayed in Fig. 8(g–i), the calculated values of D Li + of all samples during the lithiation and delithiation processes are within the scope from 10–13 to 10–6 cm2 s−1, among which the LM0.25F0.75P/C electrode shows a relatively high D Li +, indicating superior kinetic characteristics. The illustration of the deintercalation process is displayed in Fig. 8(j). The 1D Li-ion diffusion channel along the b-axis is surrounded by the stable octahedral oxygen which ensures that the crystal structure would not collapse after the deintercalation of Li-ion. Meanwhile, the LM0.25F0.75P/C derived from the PBA retains the N element from the precursor and forms a nitrogen-doped carbon network, which facilitates superior conductivity and expedited diffusion. These experimental results illustrate that tunning the electrochemical behavior of LM x F1– x P/C for advanced lithium-ion batteries through controlling the dose of Mn-doping to obtain the MOF-derived LM x F1– x P/C with diverse morphology and optimized compositions is a promising strategy. 4 Theoretical study Density functional theory (DFT) calculation was conducted to further investigate the effect of partial substitution of Fe2+ by Mn2+ by analyzing the crystal structure parameters, Bader charge distribution, density of state (DOS), and the Li+ intercalation energies of LM x F1– x P. The LFP, LM0.25F0.75P, and LM0.5F0.5P models were constructed and optimized to analyze the Bader charge distribution, further disclosing the effect of different content of Mn-doping on the electronic structure and charge distribution in LM x F1– x P. As shown in Fig. 9 (a), a charge redistribution occurs around the FeO6 octahedron with the Mn-doping. The charge around the O atoms between the FeO6 octahedron in the LM0.25F0.75P is the less negative one, compared with the pristine LFP and LM0.5F0.5P (more details of charge distribution are displayed in Fig. S19). The models in Fig. 9(b) depict the 1D Li-ion diffusion channel along the b-axis, which is surrounded by octahedral oxygen. Therefore, the less negative charge weakens the attraction between the diffused Li-ion and the closed oxygen anions (O2–), facilitating accelerated Li migration [66]. Furthermore, the total (nominated as TDOS) and partial (nominated as PDOS) density of states bound up with the Fermi level (E f) were carried out to analyze the electronic structure for LM x F1– x P in Fig. 9(c). It was confirmed that the LM0.25F0.75P exhibits a band gap of 3.20 eV (Fig. S20), lower than those of LFP (3.48 eV) and LM0.5F0.5P (3.41 eV), indicating a superior electronic conductivity of LM0.25F0.75P which is attributed to the optimized crystal structure resulting from the proper Mn amount doping. To investigate the kinetics and deintercalation behaviors in LM x F1– x P, we constructed the mono-vacancy LM x F1– x P models by removing a single Li atom to calculate the Li ion deintercalation energy in Fig. 9(d). The energy can be quantified by the following formula [67]. (6) Δ E n 1 , n 2 = E t o t L i n 1 F e P O 4 + n 2 - n 1 E t o t L i - E t o t L i n 2 F e P O 4 (7) Δ E n 1 , n 2 = E tot Li n 1 Mn x Fe 1 - x PO 4 + n 2 - n 1 E tot Li - E tot ( Li n 2 Mn x Fe 1 - x PO 4 ) where the ΔE refers to the energy variation upon deintercalation of Li ion from LFP, LM0.25F0.75P, and LM0.5F0.5P, while the E tot stands for the total energy of the corresponding system and E tot (Li) represents the electrode potential of fcc metallic lithium. The energy of deintercalation for one single Li atom in optimized LM x F1– x P models were calculated by the above equations. As displayed in Fig. S21, the E tot (Li) is calculated as –1.997 eV. On this basis, the energy of Li+ deintercalation processes for LFP, LM0.25F0.75P, and LM0.5F0.5P are calculated as 4.602, 4.147, and 5.484 eV, respectively. Consequently, the LM0.25F0.75P needs to overcome the lowest energy barrier of 4.147 eV to realize the Li+ deintercalation process, indicating the enhanced Li+ diffusion and accelerated deintercalation kinetics. These results theoretically confirmed that proper Mn-doping can manipulate the charge distribution and optimize crystal compositions, thus facilitating easier Li+ deintercalation, minimized diffusion energy barrier, and enhanced electrochemical kinetics. 5 Conclusions In summary, we designed a facile atomic modulation strategy for the fabrication of the MOF-derived LM x F1– x P/C (x = 0, 0.25, 0.5) cathode materials via a feasible solid-state annealing method. The diverse morphologies and tunable electrochemical performance for LM x F1– x P/C are obtained by regulating the content of dopant Mn2+ in the corresponding MOF self-sacrificial templates. Among LM x F1– x P/C materials, the LM0.25F0.75P/C exhibits superior cycle life and enhanced rate performance, which should be attributed to the optimized Mn-doping crystal, porous morphology with enormous specific surface area, N-doped conductive carbon matrix, and favorable (de)lithiation mechanism. According to the ex-situ high-resolution XRD measurements, the (de)lithiation mechanism of LM0.25F0.75P/C can be explained by a donating single-phase solid solution transition accompanied with a slight two-phase transition. Compared with the two-phase transition process of LFP/C, the single-phase solid solution transition can avoid major structural rearrangements and volume changes, thus effectively minimizing the Li-ion transport barrier and boosting the electronic conductivity. As confirmed by DFT calculation, LM0.25F0.75P/C exhibits the smallest band gap and lowest energy for Li+ deintercalation processes, indicating enhanced Li+ diffusion and accelerated deintercalation kinetics. This MOF self-sacrificing strategy paves a promising avenue for the design of advanced transition metal phosphate-based cathode materials by tailoring the morphological features and manipulating the finite amounts of dopant ions. coredata.dc:description: LiFePO4, as a prevailing cathode material for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), still encounters issues such as intrinsic poor electronic conductivity, inferior Li-ion diffusion kinetic, and two-phase transformation mechanism involving substantial structural rearrangements, resulting in unsatisfactory rate performance. Carbon coating, cation doping, and morphological control have been widely employed to reconcile these issues. Inspired by these, we propose a synthetic route with metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) as self-sacrificial templates to simultaneously realize shape modulation, Mn doping, and N-doped carbon coating for enhanced electrochemical performances. The as-synthesized LiMn x Fe1– x PO4/C (x = 0, 0.25, and 0.5) deliver tunable electrochemical behaviors induced by the MOF templates, among which LiMn0.25Fe0.75PO4/C outperforms its counterparts in cyclability (164.7 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.5 C) and rate capability (116.3 mA h g−1 at 10 C). Meanwhile, the ex-situ XRD reveals a dominant single-phase solid solution mechanism of LiMn0.25Fe0.75PO4/C during delithiation, contrary to the pristine LiFePO4, without major structural reconstruction, which helps to explain the superior rate performance. Furthermore, the density functional theory (DFT) calculations verify the effects of Mn doping and embody the superiority of LiMn0.25Fe0.75PO4/C as a LIB cathode, which well supports the experimental observations. This work provides insightful guidance for the design of tunable MOF-derived mixed transition-metal systems for advanced LIBs.
